name: coComment
overview:
coComment is a service that lets people keep track of all their separate comments and discussions which they are part of on the web. Much like an e-mail inbox, coComment notifies users of new comment posts while also displaying any comments and conversations that a user may be tracking on sites such as blogs, news sites, and photosharing sites. coComment’s website has a complete list of compatible platforms than can be tracked including, for instance, popular sites like Digg and Flickr. For bloggers, coComment is useful because it lets them display comments made elsewhere back on their own blogs as well. coComment is free and the company’s browser extension can easily be downloaded from the website.

According to coComment’s own web-page (as of 17th February 2012) … “The service will be switched off at 31.3.2012 at midnight 12:00 am.” The main webserver can no longer be reached.

funding_rounds.source_description: coComment wants to monetize online conversations

milestones.description: Cocomment adds automated moderation and desktop widget
milestones.source_text:
SAN FRANCISCO, CA - July 28, 2008 - coComment (www.cocomment.com), the
leading platform for managing, powering and researching conversations
online, today announced the launch of major features and upgrades to allow
users and site owners to more effectively manage, access and display their
conversations. The company announced enhancements to its moderation
technology for site owners that will allow them to delegate moderation and
define parameters on comments. Additionally, the company is announcing a
consumer-facing Google Desktop widget that will let users to more easily
track their comments on the desktop.

For the first time, coComment's site owners have automated moderation
capabilities to more effectively define parameters for comments left on
their sites and control disruptive content by letting them define unwanted
keywords or phrases to be prevented. The new enhancements also allow users
to delegate additional moderators and assign moderation rights and
capabilities.

coComment's new Google Desktop widget displays a user's last active
conversation (with a popup for comments) without the need to even have a
browser open. The widget also enables all of a user's conversations across
Facebook and most other sites, to be displayed as well.

Additional coComment upgrades also include:
.        Technorati top100 - automated crawling of the new posts and comments
for each blog
.        RSS feeds - new page with all available feeds for a user
.        Email notification - notification of updated conversations (daily
and weekly)
.        New complete German translation

Matt Colebourne, coComment CEO, commented: "We're seeing a massive increase
in the popularity of commenting and wanted to increase usability and add
value to the overall experience for our users. We strive to bring our users
first-to-market solutions and will continue to make strides that will keep
coComment in the frontline of online conversations."

About coComment
Founded in 2007, coComment is the leading platform for managing, powering
and researching conversations online. The company enables better
conversations on the web by providing users the ability to centralize, track
and share comments anywhere online. Through integration with major media
companies and publishing platforms, coComment increases the visibility and
exposure of comments to a greater user base of active commenters, bloggers
and the public  - creating more interesting user experiences, driving users
to the commenting sites and linking conversations with a community.
coComment is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.  More information can be
found at: www.coComment.com

Media contact
Paul Brady
Consort Partners
cocomment@consortpartners.com
Tel:  +1 (646) 491-2777

-----Original Message-----
From: Mark Hendrickson [mailto:mark@techcrunch.com]
Sent: Sunday, July 27, 2008 10:58 PM
To: Paul Brady
Subject: Re: coComment exclusive for TechCrunch: Please respond ASAP

What's the desktop widget built in? (AIR, etc?) And what kind of
parameters can be set for comments?

Mark

Paul Brady wrote:
>
> Hi Mark,
>
> We haven't worked together, but my colleague, Kathy Johnson, said you
> would likely be interested in doing an exclusive with our client
> coComment, a platform for managing conversations online (boiler
> below). coComment is launching a new feature set and want to offer
> TechCrunch the exclusive.
>
> The company is announcing exciting enhancements to its moderation
> technology for site owners that will allow them to define parameters
> on comments and delegate moderation. Additionally, the company is
> announcing a consumer facing desktop widget that will extend
> distribution and ease-of-use for its users. They are also announcing
> several other upgrades including RSS feeds and more.
>
> We were hoping to get you in a briefing early today with Matt
> Colebourne, CEO at coComment, and offer the news to you guys
> exclusively for the announcement.
>
> Please let me know ASAP if you are interested in this and I will send
> the release. Unfortunately, we need to get this news out soon if possible.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Paul
>
> Tel. 646-491-2777
>
> www.cocomment.com <http://www.cocomment.com>
>

> centralize, track and share comments anywhere online. Through
> integration with major media companies and publishing platforms,
> coComment increases the visibility and exposure of comments to a
> greater user base of active commenters, bloggers and the public -
> creating more interesting user experiences, driving users to the
> commenting sites and linking conversations with a community. coComment
> is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland. More information can be found

milestones.source_description: COCOMMENT ANNOUNCES FEATURE UPGRADES Automated moderation gives site owners more control; Google Desktop widget extends distribution and ease-of-use for consumers
